title: Black People are never "Black Enough" and I'll prove it
description:
üß° Get YOUR name in future videos (and support the channel): https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles/
üí¨ Talk to me 1-on-1: https://calendly.com/laytonobserves

‚úèÔ∏è BRAND NEW SUBSTACK: https://laytonwrites.substack.com/

Today, we investigate what separates "real black people" from "race traitors" (otherwise known as uncle toms, oreos, and cxxns). Through the spectrum of Doctor Umar Johnson's ideology of race, we shall evaluate the "psychological purity," of people like: Kanye West (Ye), Tyler the Creator, Candace Owens, Drake, Doja Cat, Aba and Preach, FD Signifier, Lil Wayne and more, by analysing their interviews, podcasts, debates and controversial appearances. Themes include: black conservatives, BLM, interracial dating,  and "snow bunnies."

‚ùó Subscribe! https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCV78KlDDsXgeKAGO3a8QzKQ?sub_confirmation=1

title: The Video Essay Problem
description:
üß° Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles/about
üí∏ "Good job" tip: Laytonicles https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/laytonicles

They go by many names: video essayists, commentary channels, overly opinionated pretentious yappers. YouTube is home to a genre of video known as the "video essay"; a genre dedicated to analysing everything from film and TV to pop culture and social media trends. Since video essays tend to look outwards for their object of analysis, today we're going to turn the magnifying glass inward, by analysing video essayists, video essays and their audience. Together, we shall uncover the psychological and philosophical motivations for watching video essays, and the problems associated with them.

‚ùó Click to Subscribe! https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCV78KlDDsXgeKAGO3a8QzKQ?sub_confirmation=1

title: The Book Kendrick Used To Destroy Drake
description:
üß° Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles/
üí∏ "Good job" tip: Laytonicles https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/laytonicles
Kendrick Lamar and Drake have been in competition with one another for over a decade. This year, their "sneak disses" became much more overt following Drake and J Cole's First Person Shooter, with Kendrick Lamar responding on Like That, and then Euphoria and Not Like Us. It's unanimous that Kendrick Lamar beat Drake; we don't need another timeline explained video to prove that. What we do need, however, is an anlysis of the rap beef through the lens of power. Which is why I've created just that.

title: The Day Donald Glover "Became Black"
description:
üß° Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles/

Donald Glover, AKA Childish Gambino, is a modern day renaissance man with talents comprising acting, writing, stand-up comedy, singing, rapping and beyond. However, a "talent" Mr Bando Stone, at least once upon a time, didn't have was the acceptance of "being black." Until recent years, he was a racial outcast. Which is what we'll be exploring in this video essay: The Day Donald Glover Became Black.

title: You don't need "Alpha Male" advice, you need Jungian Masculinity
description:
üß° Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles/
üí∏ "Good job" tip: Laytonicles https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/laytonicles
üëï Laytonicles Shop (become immortal) https://www.laytonicles-shop.com/

Comprised of so-called "Alpha Males," the Manosphere is an online community teaching men how to become like them; an attractive, masculine sigma/alpha male, resulting in an increase of - what's being dubbed - "toxic masculinity." But with little to no role models, who/what else are modern men supposed to turn to? Here, I propose an alternative: True Masculinity, otherwise known as Heroic Masculinity, Mythopoetic Masculinity or Jungian Masculinity. Because currently, what is actually being taught by these "high value" men is masculinity's opposite: shadow masculinity
 Let us deconstruct, analyse and debunk the "masculinity" being propagated by the red pill community and put forth an alternative paradigm - together.

üé¨ Watch this BONUS analysis of my masculinity HERE: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tG5oHM1eaoM

title: The Red Pill is over (How the Manosphere failed men)
description:
üß° Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles/about
üí∏ "Good job" tip: Laytonicles https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/laytonicles

The Red Pill is an ideology (or praxeology, according to its founder "Rational Male" Rollo Tomassi) that has been rising within the Manosphere over the past few years. However, with key players in the scene disavowing or claiming it over - such as Tate and Sneako - and viewers gradually turning away from the likes of Fresh and Fit and the Whatever podcast, it would appear its popularity is now on decline. Today, we expose and debunk some of the Red Pill's biggest lies, about men, women and SMV.

üé¨ Watch Deconstructing the Manosphere (Red Pill, "The Wall", "Easy Mode" and Power Games): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3s3OTPRHH9I

title: "Alpha Males" are lying to men | Red Pill Exposed
description:

The Red Pill is an ideology within the Manosphere that has grown in influence and prominence over the past few years. This is, in part, due to the influence of podcasts such as Fresh and Fit, JustPearlyThings and the Whatever Podcast. However, other characters and online personalities such as Aba and Preach, Destiny, Hamza Ahmed, Sneako, Jordan Peterson and Tate are also mentioned in relation to the Manosphere. The question is, then: Is the Red Pill and Manosphere merely a refuge for young men to self improve or a propagator of online misogyny? In this video essay, I will...

Dating Apps are the most popular inception point for love, romance and relationships in the 21st century. What was once considered an awe-inducing rite of passage is now a series of inputs and outputs, probability calculations, zeros and ones. Enter, the Digitisation of Love.
With said digitisation of love comes a whole host of new phenomena and neologisms, like: red pill, blue pill, manosphere, looksmaxxing, ghosting, wokefishing, incel and f**kboy. How do you think dating apps will alter the trajectory of humanity? Sounds off in the comments down below!

title: The Unexpected Audience of Jordan Peterson
description:
üß° Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles/about
üí∏ "Good job" tip: Laytonicles https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/laytonicles
üëï Laytonicles Shop (become immortal) https://www.laytonicles-shop.com/

Dr Jordan B Peterson cemented himself into public consciousness as "the controversial psychologist" during his debate with Cathy Newman. Since then, he has delivered hundreds of lectures, published multiple books (including 12 Rules For Life), and has generally grown in popularity ever since. He is a central character within many online subcultures - The Manosphere - being one of them. However, one subculture The Discourse‚Ñ¢ has not reached discussion on - is his influence and appeal to young Black Men. 

00:00 Teaser
01:06 Intro
04:37 Why do People like Jordan Peterson (Collective Unconscious & Archetypes)
16:36 Why do Men like Jordan Peterson (Men, Masculinity, Man-Children and Dopamine)
21:43 Why do Black Men like Jordan Peterson?

title: Exposing what "Progressives" really think of Black People | White Fragility Sequel Review
description:
üß° Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles
‚ùó Watch the series from beginning to end here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wJg2BvJZQAo&list=PLmY6uKqMZl5CFpORE1idCeMh3j3uSokOr&index=1

White Fragility was, and continues to be, one of the seminal texts herding "progressives"/leftists on topics such as: critical race theory (CRT), anti-racism (antiracism), inclusivity, representation, oppression, social justice, white privilege, and identity politics. Now, the daughter of White Fragility - Nice Racism - seeks to continue its parent's legacy. And so, I - certified "Person of Colour" - wanted to review it. And review it I did.
In this video, we discuss:

00:00 Teaser
00:33 Introduction
06:43 Race Essentialism
16:48 How "Anti-Racists" See Black People
29:23 Black People Are "Never Wrong"
42:47 How "Anti-Racists" See Themselves
50:37 Robin's History & Psychology
1:00:33 "Anti-Racism" is a Religion
1:08:36 - Closer

I intend to pause on talking about race and racism for a while after this. So, I would like to thank - and for those of you looking for extra contemplations and conversations on race, I urge you to turn to follow - Coleman Hughes, Ayishat Akanbi, Sheena Mason, Africa Brooke and John McWhorter.

Thank you for watching. Thank you for reading :)

title: "White Progressives are the MOST R*cist" - Let's See‚Ä¶ | White Fragility Sequel | Nice Racism Review
description:
üß° Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/laytonicles
‚ñ∂Ô∏è NEXT Episode: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M9O4oJv1RhY

"White Fragility," a polarising book, is the most popular representation of anti-racist ideas. Written by PhD Robin Diangelo, it acts as a manual by white people for white people; outlining methods and personal anecdotes about combatting racism. Now, three years, and 100 weeks on the NYT best sellers list later, Robin, returns with the sequel: Nice Racism. And so, too, do I return with another review... What will I, an actual black person, think?
Throughout this video, we shall explore: the academic meaning of "whiteness", credentialing, "out-woking" and cancel culture, objectification, diversity, representation and tokenism, interracial dating and the idea that "white silence is violence."

title: Calls Herself R*cist. Becomes Millionaire | White Fragility Review
description:
‚ùóWatch the previous entry in this saga here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iTGIO9_QqGg

White Fragility is the most popular representation of critical race theory. Written by PhD Robin Diangelo, the book acts as a manual by white people for white people; outlining methods and personal anecdotes about combatting racism.

Diangelo delivers talks to audiences predominantly consisting of white people, and her book is read by, again, predominantly white people. However, did anybody stop and think what an actual black person thought?
Hi, I'm actual black person, embarked on an adventure investigating this cultural phenomenon that has now enjoyed over 100 weeks on the New York Times Best Seller list.

Is White Fragility a museum - filled with interesting, invigorating artefacts wall to wall? Or is it a sausage? (Good enough on the outside, but filled with a contents you'd rather not know about)

Come along with me, your certified Person of Colour‚Ñ¢, as we analyse, critique and review this text together.

‚ùó Subscribe! http://youtube.com/laytonontoast?sub_confirmation=1

üîé  Watch my preliminary thoughts here:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6sFdi5iZJ5Q

title: A Critical Review of White Fragility: What an actual black person thinks
description:
‚ùó Watch The Final Part Here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jU0fwYr_gME

Though originally published in 2018, Robin Diangelo‚Äôs White Fragility is currently experiencing a - het-hem - second spike.. From being number 1 on Amazon, to its author appearing on Jimmy Fallon (which is about as mainstream as you can get) it‚Äôs self evidently a viral cultural phenomenon‚Ä¶ amongst white people. Which, self admitted by Diangelo, is the book‚Äôs target demographic...

BUT did anybody consider what actual black people thought? Hi, I‚Äôm actual black people, and today we‚Äôll be continuing our investigation into the world of White Fragility.

Today we‚Äôre well and truly in there like swimwear, covering Chapters 1 - 3. We cover Robin‚Äôs presuppositions on race, including the idea of it merely being a social construct, racism being an omnipresent force and the credence of ‚Äúrace science." We also shed light on what White Fragility gets right, because grey is an under-utilised colour.

Call this a review of sorts; a critique, a commentary, a response, a discussion, a debunk, SYNONYMS. Does White Fragility stand up to scrutiny, or is it postmodern critical race theory bla bla? Well, unlike the cover of white Fragility, perhaps it‚Äôs not so‚Ä¶ black and white. ‚ÄúWow, I love a good pun,‚Äù says the crowd.

Here is‚Ä¶ White Fragility: The Good, The Bad and The Ugly

title: White Fragility: What an Actual Black Person Thinks
description:
‚ùó Watch Part 2 (including quotes with page numbers, analysis and "jokes") here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iTGIO9_QqGg&list=PLmY6uKqMZl5DEdegsGqCgOuYrP8g-ARLp

White Fragility was released over two years ago, but, due to [gestures] _recent events_, it has gotten a resurgence; becoming more mainstream than ever before. The book's author, Robin Diangelo, has been invited to join Jimmy Fallon, as well as countless others, to discuss her book, which, self admittedly, is aimed at a white audience. HOWEVER, did anybody stop to consider what actual black people thought?
Hi, I'm actual black people, and today we'll be beginning our investigation into the ideas, themes and convictions of White Fragility, hopefully in a light and humourous (cringe) way. Call it a review of sorts; a critique, a commentary, a reaction, a discussion. Are all white people racist? Or is white fragility a kafta-trap? How can you (YOU) be less racist? Find out on the next episode of Dragon B-- I mean Laytonicles.

Here is... White Fragility: What an Actual Black Person Thinks
